history.content: Time commitment: depends on your level of commitment- minimum of 5 (though that's probably not worth your time), typically ten+.  Professors/grad students are aware that as an undergrad you have a lot on your plate, so are understanding if you can't work during a midterm week for instance (and are aware that you are usually an unpaid volunteer too).  As an undergraduate, you will typically start off with a task that is menial and not very fun (otherwise the graduate student would have done it him/herself), but if you learn the material and give a good commitment you will be entrusted with better projects, and you may eventually even get to do original research of your own.  Is it harder to be a student? Yes, since you are now devoting hours away from classes- and ideally the research becomes so fun you find yourself focusing on the research more than school!  In sum, imo it's worth trying out- maybe you will enjoy it (remember, every grad student was once an undergraduate researcher too!), and if you don't, you can always quit at the end of the semester.

Yes, since you are now devoting hours away from classes- and ideally the research becomes so fun you find yourself focusing on the research more than school!  In sum, imo it's worth trying out- maybe you will enjoy it (remember, every grad student was once an undergraduate researcher too!), and if you don't, you can always quit at the end of the semester.

How time consuming is it? Do you make your own hours? Does it make being a student severely more difficult? What work do undergraduates do? Etc.
history.subject: What is it like researching during the semester?
